column1: Dewayne Dedmon

It's easy to fill out the 5 spot if you have everything else. Jordan, LeBron and Curry mostly won with nothing at the 5.   Javale McGee and/or Dewayne Dedmon fix up the defense. I don't see PJ Tucker being bought out, with all the trade rumors around him.  Dewayne Dedmon and Ersan Ilyasova are both tough bigs, getting up there in age so they could be washed. Maybe Tyler Zeller.  For buyouts, its early to speculate. Not too many definite out of the playoff teams except Detroit. Cleveland has 3 centers that are at least rotation players, so I imagine McGee gets bought out. The Sixers have 4, which they like to have for Embiid insurance. But they could drop Pourier/Bradley if a good buyout guard/wing is available (they still have their full taxpayers MLE to use).

Dewayne Dedmon, John Henson, Ersan Ilyasova, Ian Mahinmi, Joakim Noah are all free agents. Not the ideal options obviously, but gotta be worth Brooklyn taking a flyer on with a non guaranteed deal right? I mean what do they have to lose. Don‚Äôt have much assets left and these guys could be had for just about nothing. Doesn‚Äôt work, waive ‚Äòem.
Alright. Cool. Any free agent centres that aren't complete ass? (Checks)  Ian Mahinmi, Skal Labissiere, Dewayne Dedmon, John Henson... yeah, I'm sure at least one of them could be serviceable.

I think this isn't a bad idea by any means. People can clown the idea but at the end of the day the Nets are in desperate need for big depth. If you can get Whiteside for a second rounder then I'd go for it.   Are we forgetting that last year he averaged 15.5/13.5 and lead the league in blocks? I get that his skillset isn't what the NBA is trending towards but I'm still surprised he's rotting away in Sac on a vet min.  There's also the argument to make though that they can easily get someone else that's either more productive or is a free buyout. JaVale McGee makes a lot of sense if they can get him on the cheap. Dewayne Dedmon is a great candidate as a buyout center as well.
What about Dewayne Dedmon?
Why not pick up someone off waivers like Cheick Diallo or Dewayne Dedmon? They're not exactly stars but I feel like they'd be nice fits. I actually don't understand why Diallo is out of the league
Play kyle korver as a sf/pf? come on. It seems obvious to me they need to sign Dewayne Dedmon not Frank Kaminsky who is not a free agent.

I think their best shot though is trading for JaVale McGee, he's a cheap rim-runner you could get for a second probably.
Dewayne Dedmon is available.  If JaVale gets bought out it's a decent idea.
Dewayne Dedmon, he's a free agent right now.  Nets might try to pick him up since they need a center.

My only issue with this is how few centers are genuinely good shooters and are starting caliber players.  They could definitely get a better shooter than Adams - but will they have to sacrifice in other areas to do that?  Kings signed Dewayne Dedmon to a substantial contract largely cause he could shoot and that ended up being a bust.  But I guess it depends on the trade value for him.  If he is seen as a starting level center, that 2/35 extension is fine imo, that is a movable trade asset for the next three years.  But there are a lot of quality centers, so if he isn't actually a clear starting caliber guy, then it is a bad value.  It isn't that easy to just sign a starting caliber player outright in FA.

In his first four seasons in the league, Dewayne Dedmon didn't shoot threes at all. The next three seasons he shot approximately three a game. He went from shooting approximately 60% of his field goals from within 3 feet to around 30% in that same time. In his 3 seasons at Atlanta he shot .358 from distance, pretty decent for a centre. He was shooting sub 70% from the free throw line early and became a plus 80% shooter.

Yeah, KP is in the tier of ‚Äúserious 3 point threats‚Äù, not just ‚Äúbigs who can make wide open 3s‚Äù.  The spacing from someone like KP is a lot more significant than spacing from a big like Kelly Olynyk or Dewayne Dedmon. KP‚Äôs a good enough shooter that his defender is a lot less likely to help off of him, which helps the rest of the team even if KP never touches the ball. Most stretch-5s don‚Äôt actually provide that much spacing because you can help off of them and live off of the one 3 they make per game

If Tyler Herro had a breakout year this would be different in my mind, but nah I didn‚Äôt expect the Heat to beat a top 3 seed without a ton of luck.

No, they didn't. Sources came out with Houston's asking price.  - Herro, Duncan, Precious & Nunn (combined salary: $9,732,122) - Salary Filler ($31,522,798 worth) - Two 1st-Round Picks (miami only has their 2022/2024) - 4 Pick Swaps (legitimately did not have enough picks to swap)  That means mortgaging the future in two ways: the young players **and** the pick economy for 2-and-a-half years of James Harden. Not to mention that Miami's only way to create the filler would've been to trade Olynyk & Iguodala for Harden at the last minute.  But fuck it, because *Oh please...* came so easily to you, here's what the roster makeup would've looked like fresh out of the trade, completely ignoring that we didn't have the picks or the swaps for Houston.  PG: Goran Dragic/Gabe Vincent (2-Way)  SG: James Harden/Max Strus (2-Way)  SF: Jimmy Butler/Trevor Ariza (who was acquired with a 2027 SRP + meyers)  PF: Nemanja Bjelica/KZ Okpala   C: Bam Adebayo/Dewayne Dedmon (f/a signing)  If you think **that** 10-man rotation does any better against the Milwaukee Bucks than the one we've pushed out there twice, you're completely out of your mind. Ok‚Ä¶ I guess I could have worded that better. NBA players can not publicly make trade demands at all, because they are under contract and therefore bound by the rules of the CBA.  This is why all trade demands are essentially ‚Äúsources say player X wants a trade‚Äù rather than the player saying it themselves.  https://www.nba.com/news/anthony-davis-fined-trade-demand-nba-official-release  https://www.nba.com/news/dewayne-dedmon-fined-trade-request-official-release

I don‚Äôt recall Kobe getting in trouble. Not sure if it was preferential treatment, or more likely just that the CBA rules were different.  Here are some recent examples of players getting fined for this (but also, LOL at Dedmon feeling like he had the power to demand a trade)  https://www.nba.com/news/dewayne-dedmon-fined-trade-request-official-release  https://www.nba.com/news/anthony-davis-fined-trade-demand-nba-official-release

Their scouting and player development is solid; they find hidden gems not only in the draft but in the pool of undrafted players. Their G-League program keeps churning out rotation players (Rodney McGruder, Tyler Johnson, Josh Richardson, Duncan Robinson). They seem to get the best out of guys, even revitalizing discarded veterans (Wayne Ellington, Dewayne Dedmon, Birdman, Anthony Mason had his only All-Star year with the Heat). They employ a lot of their former players: Anthony Carter, Keith Askins, Alonzo Mourning, Glen Rice, Chris Quinn, Shane Battier, Malik Allen, Caron Butler, Kasib Powell.

>The Heat improved their immediate title odds the most  Did they?  Lowry is a championship caliber PG, but they're losing Dragic so that's not a huge step forward.  Re-signing Robinson was a relief, but they already had him so it doesn't make the team better.  PJ Tucker is a nice piece, but he averaged 3.7ppg this year and is a total zero offensively on everything but corner 3's. Dewayne Dedmon played well in a very small sample size this year, but he's a 32 year old journeyman who's spent most of the last decade as a roster filler on 25 win squads.  Seems like this team is perfectly set up to enter the 2022 playoffs as the 6 seed while being *wildly* overconfident that their veteran experience will carry them.  That strategy has been attempted many times and virtually never works.

Luckily we seem to have turned a new leaf with Monte McNair, it‚Äôs only been a season and some change but it‚Äôs looked a looooot better.  So yeah in terms of who‚Äôve we drafted, nobody‚Äôs gone on to have an all-star type season besides IT. We lost a lot. People talk about us gaining Lowry and that‚Äôs great, but he is much older than he was even when he won a championship.   Beyond that, from our 2020 Finals run, we lost, Dragic, Crowder, Olynyk, Iguodala, Derrick Jones Jr., Nunn and Meyers Leonard.   We‚Äôve added old Lowry, old PJ Tucker, Markief Morris and Dewayne Dedmon.   Really and truly, I don‚Äôt expect too much production out of Morris and Dedmon and even with them we lost 7 rotation guys and added 4. The ones we added are older and our bench is shorter. We went from being 11 deep to about 7 deep unless Okpala and Gabe Vincent to actually earn more minutes which they really haven‚Äôt as of yet.   It‚Äôs hard to win a championship without solid bench production and nobody on our bench really pops, scares a team, or does really anything so well as to be incredibly positive for us.
